journal-meta.journal-title: Transactions of the Institute of Measurement and Control

title-group.article-title: Improved synchronization criteria for a class dynamical complex network with internal delay

contrib-group.aff: College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou China

author-notes.corresp: Wenjun Yan, College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310027, China Email: yanwenjun_zju@163.com

abstract.p: This paper is concerned with the synchronization problem for Lur’e-type dynamical complex networks with time-varying delay. The problem of non-linear time-varying delayed Lur’e-type dynamical networks are changed into the corresponding stabilization situation of dynamical error systems. Based on the improved Lyapunov–Krasovskii functional, which utilizes the information of time-varying delay adequately, some new synchronization criteria are derived via a linear matrix inequality with different sector conditions. Furthermore, by using an eigenvalue-decoupling method, high-dimension criteria are decoupled into low-dimension ones and the complexity of the criterion computation is reduced. Then the numerical examples are carried out to demonstrate the applicability and effectiveness of the proposed work through simulations.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Over the past decades, the research of phenomena in dynamical complex networks has attracted increasing attention, due to the great significance both in theory and application (Albert and Barabasi, 2002; Li et al., 2006; Newman, 2003; Park et al., 2006; Strogatz, 2001; Wang, 2002; Watts and Strogatz, 1998). The complex network is a set of coupled nodes, in which each node is a fundamental or basic unit with specific dynamics, and most real-life infrastructure networks can be modelled by dynamical complex networks, including the World Wide Web (WWW), social networks, electric power grids, etc. (Boccaletti et al., 2006; Costa et al., 2007; Girvan and Newman, 2002; Newman, 2006). In particular, one interesting and significant phenomenon in the dynamical properties of complex networks is the synchronization motion of their dynamical elements. Therefore, much research has been focused on this topic and several pioneering results of synchronization techniques for complex networks have been achieved in the literature (Arenas and Guilera, 2007; Arenas et al., 2008; Gardenes et al., 2007; Lodato et al., 2007).

Recently, the synchronization problem of the delayed Lur’e system, complex networks or neural networks has received a great deal of attention (Cao et al., 2005; Duan et al., 2008; Guo and Zhong, 2007; Han, 2005; Han and Yue, 2007; Ji et al., 2010; Xiang et al., 2007; Wang et al., 2002; Xu et al., 2008; Xu et al., 2009; Xu and Yang, 2009; Yalcin et al., 2001). One important reason is that the different synchronization problems can be defined and ascribed to the category of absolute stability issue about Lur’e or other homologous systems. Furthermore, time delay is often considered to be ubiquitous in the real world and is common in various practical application fields. Because system instability is mainly due to the intrinsic time delay, more and more researchers have stated that the phenomenon of time delay existing in dynamical complex networks cannot be ignored in the synchronization or stability analysis of such systems. To address this issue, the corresponding problem has been discussed and some conclusions have been drawn. The Lur’e–Postnikov functional technique was employed by Cao et al. (2005) and inequality methods were proposed for the master–slave type of chaos synchronization for Lur’e systems. Since system transformation and bounding techniques may take the additional conservativeness, the free-weighting matrix and Libniz–Newton formula methods were exploited by Guo and Zhong (2007) to solve the problems. Xiang et al. (2007) considered the master–slave synchronization of the Lur’e system with time delay. This article improved the results in Yalcin et al. (2001) by using the integral inequality method. Xu and Yang (2009) proposed synchronization conditions for a class of complex dynamical networks, in which the every node in the system is a time-delayed Lur’e system. However, it is worth noting that the delay conditions considered in these papers are constant ones. Very recently, Ji et al. (2010) analysed the synchronization problem for Lur’e-type complex dynamical networks with time-varying delay, and the less conservative sufficient conditions were proposed in the form of linear matrix inequalities (LMIs), based on the projection lemma and delay-dividing technique. In this method, the authors employed the central point variation of the delay and the time-varying one is divided into two equal subintervals. However, when the lower bound d is not zero, this method becomes unavailable. Noting the statements above, some unsolved and challenging problems still remain as follows.

list-item.p: The delay conditions considered in the previous work are constant or time varying with the zero lower bound. The more general time-varying delay case, whose lower bound is non-zero, is still unexplored.

Approaches such as the Lyapunov–Krasovskii functional, integral inequality and free-weighting matrix have been proposed to reduce the conservativeness. However, there still exists room for further investigation.
As a powerful tool, the Kronecker product plays an important role in problem transformation. However, it brings a rapid increase in decision variables and computation complexity.

sec.p: Motivated by these considerations, the synchronization problem for general delayed Lur’e-type complex dynamical networks is investigated. The synchronization problem is transformed into the corresponding stabilization problem. The improved Lyapunov–Krasovskii method is proposed to explore the delay-dependent absolute stability problem. The ignored integral term −∫t−h2t−h(t)h12x·T(s)Zx·(s)ds in the previous work is utilized based on the convex combination technique. The delay-dependent absolute stability criteria are derived in terms of LMIs. It should be pointed out that the results by using the Kronecker product are high dimensional and hard to verify. Therefore, by using an eigenvalue-decoupling method, high-dimension criteria are decoupled into low-dimension ones and the complexity of the criterion computation is reduced. As the main index of measuring the conservativeness of criteria, the maximum allowable delay bound (MADB) problems are provided to corroborate the effectiveness of the proposed methods.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. The problem statement and preliminaries are introduced in Section 2. The synchronization problem for delayed Lur’e-type dynamical complex networks is studied and synchronization criteria are proposed in Section 3. Section 4 shows the effectiveness of the derived results. Conclusions are presented in Section 5.

sec.title: Notations
sec.p: Throughout this paper, Rn denotes the n-dimensional Euclidean space, R is the set of real numbers and Rm×n is the set that represents the m×n dimensional real matrices. I denotes the identity matrix with the appropriate dimension and IL denotes the identity matrix with L×L dimension. X<0 means that X is a symmetric negative definitive matrix. The superscript ‘T’ represent the matrix transposition, respectively, if a matrix is invertible, the superscript ‘–1’ represents the matrix inverse. For the arbitrary matrix B and two symmetric matrices A, C the symmetric term in symmetric matrix is denoted by the asterisk, which is
and A⊗B indicates the Kronecker product of a n×m matrix A and a p×q matrix B, that is

sec.title: Definition 1 (Yalcin et al., 2001)
sec.p: the non-linearity f(ċ) is said to be in the sector [0Δ~], if it satisfies (4).

sec.title: Definition 2 (Xu and Yang, 2009)
sec.p: the Lur’e system described by (1) is said to be absolutely stable in the sector [0Δ~], if the system is globally uniformly asymptotically stable for any non-linear function f(ċ), which satisfies (4).

Now suppose the Lur’e-type dynamical complex network with time-varying delay, in which the coupled connection of the nodes is established by the state xi(t), i=1,2,…,L, therefore the network model can be written as

where constant c>0 represents the corresponding coupling strength and Γ=(γij)∈Rn×n is an inner-coupling matrix. H=(hij)L×L is the matrix of coupling configuration, which represents the topological structure of the network. If there exists a connection between the nodes i and j(i≠j), hij=hji=1; otherwise, hij=hji=0, (i≠j). The row sum of H are zeros, that is
that is H is an irreducible matrix.

which can be an equilibrium point or a non-periodic orbit, where σ(t)=Ms(t)+Ns(t−h(t)) are the output vectors in the each node.

Before we transform the delayed Lur’e dynamical network synchronization problem to the stabilization issue of corresponding error networks, the following statements are useful for derivation of the next steps.

sec.title: Assumption 1 (Ji et al., 2010)
sec.p: the network described by state-space model (6) is connected, that is, the network has no isolate clusters.

sec.title: Lemma 1 (Ji et al., 2010)
sec.p: The eigenvalues of an irreducible matrix H=(hij)∈RL×L with
satisfy the following properties.

list-item.p: 0 is an eigenvalue of H associated the eigenvector [1,1,…,1]T.
If hij≥0 for all 1≤i, j≤L, i≠j, then the real parts of all eigenvalues of H are less than or equal to 0. In fact, 0 is its eigenvalue of multiplicity 1.

Consequently, with this spirit, the synchronization problem of the dynamical complex network has been transformed into the stabilization problem of the corresponding Lur’e-type error dynamical system.

sec.title: Remark 1
sec.p: The non-linear function ϕ(v(t);S(t)), which satisfies (15), is considered within the sector [0,Θ] and within the sector [Θ1,Θ2], if the following inequality is satisfied:
where Θ1=IL⊗Δ1 and Θ2=IL⊗Δ2 are constant real matrices with appropriate dimension, and Θ2−Θ1 is a symmetric positive definite matrix (see Khalil (1996) for more details).

sec.title: Main results
sec.p: In this section, the synchronization criteria for the error dynamical network will be derived with different sector conditions.

sec.title: Theorem 1
sec.p: The error dynamical complex network (12) subject to (5) and (14) is absolutely stable for given scalars 0<h1<h2 and 0≤μ, if there exist symmetric positive-definite matrices P, Q1, Q2, Q3, Z1, Z2, positive-definite T and a positive scalar ε such that the following matrix inequalities hold:

sec.title: Proof
sec.p: Choose the following Lyapunov–Krasovskii functional candidate:
Taking the time derivative of Vi(et), i=1,2,3,4 with respect to t along the solutions to (12), therefore, the time derivative of the Lyapunov–Krasovskii functional can be found as
Applying Lemma 2, the following representation can be obtained:

with the definition γ=(h(t)−h1)/h12 and some algebraic manipulations, (27) takes the following form:
From the sector condition (14) it is clear that
In order to reduce the conservativeness, it is worth noting that the following equation is true for matrix T>0 with appropriate dimensions:
Combining (22)–(30), then using the S-procedure (Boyd et al., 1994), one can see that
where Π1 and Π2 are defined in (16) and (17), respectively, and

Since 0≤γ≤1, V·(et) induces a convex domain of matrices (1−γ)Π1+γΠ2 that is negative definite. Therefore, the sufficient condition Π1<0 and Π2<0 imply that the Lur’e-type dynamical complex network with internal delay (12) is absolute stable. □

sec.title: Remark 2
sec.p: the reduced conservativeness of Theorem 1 benefits from the following aspects. Firstly, the integral terms ∫t−h(t)t−h1eT(s)Q1e(s)ds and ∫t−h2t−h1eT(s)Q2e(s)ds are introduced to derive the stability condition. When the lower bound is not zero, these terms can utilize the information of time-varying delay adequately. The fact that losing the boundary condition of time delay will lead to conservativeness has been explored by Shao (2009) and Sun et al. (2010). Secondly, the derivative of (21) is often estimated as h122e·T(t)Z2e·(t)−∫t−h(t)t−h1h12e·T(s)Z2e·(s)ds in previous work. The ignored part −∫t−h2t−h(t)h12e·T(s)Z2e·(s)ds also lea{\rm d}s to considerable conservativeness. Based on the definition of γ, the convex combination technique is introduced to make these retained.

As mentioned in Remark 1, the sector condition (14) can be transformed to (15) by using loop transformation. Therefore, the error dynamical complex network (12) is equivalent to that of the following system:
As a result, the absolutely stability criterion in sector [Θ1Θ2] is equivalent to that in sector [0Θ2−Θ1] and the corresponding criterion can be stated as follows.

sec.title: Proof:
sec.p: the proof can be made simply by replacing A¯, B¯ and Θ in Theorem 1 with A¯−D¯Θ1M¯, B¯−D¯Θ1N¯ and Θ2−Θ1, respectively, which completes the proof. □

Based on the metho{\rm d}s stated above, the synchronization criteria were proposed in Theorem 1 and Theorem 2. However, there exists a situation that the information of μ is unknown or the lower bound of time-delay h1 is zero and we have the following results.

sec.p: The error dynamical complex network (32) subject to (5) and (15) is absolutely stable for given scalars 0<h1<h2, if there exist symmetric positive-definite matrices P, Q2, Z2, positive-definite T and a positive scalar ε such that the following matrix inequalities hold:

For the situation that 0<h(t)<h2 and the information of μ is unknown, we can get the following result.

sec.title: Corollary 2
sec.p: The error dynamical complex network (32) subject to (5) and (15) is absolutely stable for given scalars 0<h2, if there exist symmetric positive-definite matrices P, Q2, Z2, positive-definite T and a positive scalar ε such that the following matrix inequalities hold:
and
where

sec.title: Proof
sec.p: the proof can be established from Corollary 1 by eliminating Q3 and Z1 and setting h1=0. □

sec.title: Remark 3
sec.p: it can be seen from the results above that the size of proposed criteria is very large. When the number of the nodes in the networks increases, the number of decision variables in the proposed results will increase heavily. In other words, a large number of decision variables cause the complexity and will slow the computing process of the LMI (Boyd et al., 1994). Therefore, by setting the corresponding variable matrices into block-diagonal, the high-dimensional matrix inequality criteria are transformed into terms of lower-dimensional ones.

sec.title: Theorem 3
sec.p: The error dynamical complex network (32) subject to (5) and (15) is absolutely stable for the given scalars 0<h1<h2 and 0≤μ, if there exist symmetric positive-definite matrices Pi, Q1i, Q2i, Q3i, Z1i, Z2i, positive-definite Ti, i=1,2,…,L and a positive scalar ε such that the following 2L LMIs hold:
and
where

sec.title: Corollary 3
sec.p: The error dynamical complex network (32) subject to (5) and (15) is absolutely stable for given scalars 0<h2, if there exist symmetric positive-definite matrices Pi, Q2i, Z2i, positive-definite Ti, i=1,2,…,L and a positive scalar ε such that the following 2L LMIs hold:

sec.title: Numerical examples
sec.p: This section revisits two numerical examples of the MADB problem to assess the synchronization criteria derived in this paper in terms of conservativeness through a comparative study against existing solutions in the literature. In the first example, a traditional network system, which has been utilized in many existing literatures, is presented to validate the less conservativeness of the proposed criteria. The second network is enrolled to illustrate the effectiveness of the derived results for the dynamical complex network that each node is the delayed Lur’e system in more general form.

sec.title: Example 1
sec.p: consider in the following network that each node is a Lur’e system with time delay (L = 5), the system parameters are the same as in Ji et al. (2010), that is
and
which can be easily transformed into the form of (14) or (15).

Suppose that each part of the time-delay Lur’e system existing in the complex network is formed together through the connection between each part, that is, Γ=I and coupling strength c=1, with the assumption that the coupling connection of the whole system is described in the following matrix Γ:

By using Theorem 1 in Xu and Yang (2009), the delay bound is found to be τ = 1.22 and the synchronized states are asymptotical stable through the Matlab LMI control toolbox. By Corollary 3.1 in Ji et al. (2010), the derived results showed that the delay bound was τ = 2.80 for the given initial conditions. With Corollary 3 in this paper, the delay bound is finally τ = 2.919, which is closer to the practical allowed bound value of the maximum delay bound τ = 3.1 than the result in Ji et al. (2010).

What is worth noting is that with the L-node dynamical complex network, Corollary 3.1 in Ji et al. (2010) involves 4×n2L2+4×nL decision variables. In this paper, there are 2.5×n2L+1.5×nL+1 decision variables in Corollary 3 and it is obvious that for any situations that n≥1 and L≥1, Corollary 3 in this paper has less decision variables than Corollary 3.1 in Ji et al. (2010).

sec.title: Example 2
sec.p: considering the five-node dynamical complex network with time-varying delay, the system in this example can be selected as
and Γ=I with the coupling strength c=1:

By using Theorem 3 in this paper, the maximum delay bounds with different lower delay bounds are obtained in Table 1, and Figure 1 show the synchronization errors for the delay cases shown in Table 1 between the states of node i and node i + 1 with the following initial condition.

caption.p: Admissible upper bound h2 for various h1 and μ = 0.5
Synchronization error for Example 2 with different delays. (a) For h = 2.58 at µ = 0.5. (b) For h = 3.04 at μ = 0.5. (c) For h = 3.63 at µ = 0.5. (d) For h = 4.31 at µ = 0.5.

sec.p: Figure 1 shows that the state errors with the different delays converge to 0 with the initial condition mentioned above; therefore, the dynamical complex network with time-varying delay achieves synchronization and the effectiveness of the result proposed in this paper is demonstrated.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper, the dynamical complex network synchronization has been considered. The problem of non-linear time-varying delayed Lur’e-type dynamical networks are changed into the corresponding stabilization situation of dynamical error systems. Based on the improved Lyapunov–Krasovskii functional, which utilizes the information of time-varying delay adequately, sufficient conditions of synchronization are derived via LMI with different sector conditions. Furthermore, by using an eigenvalue-decoupling method, high-dimension criteria are decoupled into low-dimension ones and the complexity of the criterion computation is reduced. Numerical examples are provided to demonstrate that the proposed work is less conservative and faster than the existing ones.

ack.p: The authors would like to thank the Associate Editor and all the reviewers for their helpful comments.

fn.p: This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 60804045) and the Zhejiang Provincial Natural Science Foundation of China (No. Y1110229).
